pageTitle: Jered Weaver keeps moving up- Angels Blog: Orange County Register
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {12401=A couple weeks ago, I counted down the greatest Angels' pitching seasons ever, with 2010 Jered Weaver at No. 25. Since then, he's got a 2.55 ERA in 35 innings, with 29 Ks and five walks. And so, by Baseball-Reference's Wins Above Replacement, he's now up to No. 21. One more start and he's got a decent shot at moving up to No. 18., 9884=Sept. 27, 2010, 9933=Updated Aug. 21, 2013 1:17 p.m.}
textBeforeTable: He won't get Cy Young votes, or at least he won't get more than one or two third-place votes. He should get more. Besides leading the league in Ks (for the moment, at least), he is one of only three pitchers who rates well no
textAfterTable: ERA is ERA. FIP is an ERA-like stat that looks only at those things a pitcher most controls, home runs, walks and strikeouts. fWAR is Fangraphs' model of Wins Above Replacement. rWAR is Baseball Reference's model of Wins Above Replacement. VORP is Baseball Prospectus' valuation system. SNW is support-neutral wins, Baseball Prospectus' estimate of how many wins a pitcher "should" have, given an average team. You can't blame a voter for putting any of these guys (except Cahill, really) on a ballot, depending on what metric they value. But it's a shame Weaver will be overlooked. Weaver has been a top-three pitcher this year. Unfortunately, he hasn't been a top-3 "inspiring his teammates to score runs while he's sitting on the bench" pitcher this year. Blame the Angels' offense when Weaver doesn't finish in the top 3 in Cy Young voting this year. Most Popular Update:
